instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A2141: What is A2141? A2141 is a model number for a 16 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years 2019 with EMC 3347, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-01700..
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
Dear community,

I received an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> for no power. I found some issues while scanning through the microscope and also while measuring.
CB300 was short
UB300 was suspect
UB400 was suspect
L3500 was liquid damaged
<CAPACITOR>C9503</CAPACITOR> was ripped, including one of its pads.

After both UB300 and UB400 were replaced the device turned on again, but didn't take a charge from the USB-C power adapter. I tried several power adapters with sufficient watts.

At [URL]https://repair.wiki/w/A2141_2019_16%22_MacBook_Pro[/URL] I looked at the "No Power. No life on USB-C amp meter, or 5V ~ 0A." symptom and did find 3.3V on  <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H_RTC_X</SIGNAL> and 12V at <CAPACITOR>C6961</CAPACITOR>. I was not sure how to check enable signal. On the other hand, I'm not sure if I should've checked any of these, because I have no clue where the problem originates.

I do have the schematics and the boardview so I can find what you point me at, though I must emphasise that I am absolutely a junior board repairder and might ask follow-up questions which might seem pretty novice. I can measure every pin of every component you might need more info from when I can find it on the boardview.

I await your reply.

Regards,
Jelle

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum!

Where did you get the replacement <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips?
Do they have same termination code (B12)?
Some peoples mentioned to have problems and only succeeded with chips from donor <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> board.

Do you have same behavior on all USB-C ports?
Only turns on with battery connected?
Be sure to use 96/140W original charger; check its power reported by an working machine.

Check if <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> is steady high.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
Thanks for the reply,

My colleague ordered these <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips:
[URL unfurl="true"]https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/1005002555973605.html?spm=a2g0o.order_list.order_list_main.33.714779d2OhpShT&gatewayAdapt=glo2nld[/URL]
On the chip B12 is printed.
I do not have a donor of this specific model.

The behavior is the same on all four USB-C ports. I used the original power adapter and a spare one which can deliver more.

I measured <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> on pin 7 of J3000 and it reads 5.5mV. I expect that to be low and 3.3V or 5V to be high?

Edit: the above is measured with the battery disconnected and the original power adapter connected.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
That signal must stay high.
If 0V (enabled), (at least) one <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip tells to T2 (SMC) there is a problem on USB-C area.
First check <RESISTOR>R5246</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
I measured <RESISTOR>R5246</RESISTOR>.
Ohms in circuit: 2K (without power adapter)
pin 1: 1.803V (with power adapter)
pin 2: 5.8mV (with power adapter)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
If <RESISTOR>R5246</RESISTOR> is good, then one <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chip pulls down the signal.
You should find which one...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message: Is there a way to find out, or is it easier to just replace them? I already did the two easy ones. The remaining two have a plastic connector next tot them.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A2141</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> only working on battery
threads.message:
Peoples claimed on Internet to had problems replacing them on this particular board.
Not sure if works with other than chips from donor board, same model.

You may have more problems caused by corrosion.
